0: Image copyright SPL NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR HIV is evolving to become less deadly and less infectious, according to a major scientific study. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The team at the University of Oxford shows the virus is being "watered down" as it adapts to our immune systems. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It said it was taking longer for HIV infection to cause Aids and that the changes in the virus may help efforts to contain the pandemic. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Some virologists suggest the virus may eventually become "almost harmless" as it continues to evolve. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR More than 35 million people around the world are infected with HIV and inside their bodies a devastating battle takes place between the immune system and the virus. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR HIV is a master of disguise. It rapidly and effortlessly mutates to evade and adapt to the immune system. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright SPL Image caption HIV, in red, has infected a cell in the immune system, yellow. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR However, every so often HIV infects someone with a particularly effective immune system. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "[Then] the virus is trapped between a rock and hard place, it can get flattened or make a change to survive and if it has to change then it will come with a cost," said Prof Philip Goulder, from the University of Oxford. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Weakened NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The "cost" is a reduced ability to replicate, which in turn makes the virus less infectious and means it takes longer to cause Aids. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Media playback is unsupported on your device Media caption Prof Dausey, Mercyhurst University: "We have to be cautiously optimistic about this study" NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR This weakened virus is then spread to other people and a slow cycle of "watering-down" HIV begins. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The team showed this process happening in Africa by comparing Botswana, which has had an HIV problem for a long time, and South Africa where HIV arrived a decade later. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prof Goulder told the BBC News website: "It is quite striking. You can see the ability to replicate is 10% lower in Botswana than South Africa and that's quite exciting. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "We are observing evolution happening in front of us and it is surprising how quickly the process is happening. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The virus is slowing down in its ability to cause disease and that will help contribute to elimination." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Drug bonus NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The findings in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences also suggested anti-retroviral drugs were forcing HIV to evolve into milder forms. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It showed the drugs would primarily target the nastiest versions of HIV and encourage the milder ones to thrive. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prof Goulder added: "Twenty years ago the time to Aids was 10 years, but in the last 10 years in Botswana that might have increased to 12.5 years, a sort of incremental change, but in the big picture that is a rapid change. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "One might imagine as time extends this could stretch further and further and in the future people being asymptomatic for decades." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The group did caution that even a watered-down version of HIV was still dangerous and could cause Aids. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Image copyright SPL NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR HIV originally came from apes or monkeys, in which it is frequently a minor infection. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prof Jonathan Ball, a virologist at the University of Nottingham, told the BBC: "If the trend continues then we might see the global picture change - a longer disease causing much less transmission. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "In theory, if we were to let HIV run its course then we would see a human population emerge that was more resistant to the virus than we collectively are today - HIV infection would eventually become almost harmless. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "Such events have probably happened throughout history, but we are talking very large timescales." NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Prof Andrew Freedman, a reader in infectious diseases at Cardiff University, said this was an "intriguing study". NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR He said: "By comparing the epidemic in Botswana with that which occurred somewhat later in South Africa, the researchers were able to demonstrate that the effect of this evolution is for the virus to become less virulent, or weaker, over time. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR "The widespread use of antiretroviral therapy may also have a similar effect and together, these effects may contribute to the ultimate control of the HIV epidemic."
